div.p: THE TRIAL OF William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, Soldiers in his Majeſty's 29th Regiment of Foot, FOR THE MURDER OF Criſpus Attucks, Samuel Gray, Samuel Maverick, James Caldwell, and Patrick Carr, On MONDAY-EVENING, the 5th of MARCH, 1770, AT THE Superior Court of Judicature, Court of Aſſize, and general Goal Delivery, held at BOSTON. The 27th Day of November, 1770, by Adjournment. BEFORE The Hon. BENJAMIN LYNDE, JOHN CUSHING, PETER OLIVER, and EDMUND TROWBRIDGE, ESQUIRES, JUSTICES of ſaid COURT.
Publiſhed by Permiſſion of the COURT.
Taken in SHORT-HAND by JOHN HODGSON.
BOSTON: Printed by J. FLEEMING, and ſold at his PRINTING-OFFICE, nearly oppoſite the White-horſe Tavern in Newbury-ſtreet. M, DCC, LXX.

div.head: THE TRIAL OF William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, FOR THE MURDER OF Criſpus Attucks, Samuel Gray, Samuel Maverick, James Caldwell, and Patrick Carr.
The Indictment was as follows.
div.p: AT his Majeſty's Superior Court of Judicature, Court of Aſſize and general Goal Delivery, begun and held at Boſton, within, and for the County of Suffolk, on the ſecond Tueſday of March, in the tenth year of the reign of GEORGE the THIRD, by the Grace of GOD, of Great-Britain, France and Ireland, King, defender of the Faith, &c.

The Jurors for the ſaid Lord the King, upon their oath preſent, that Thomas Preſton, Eſq William Wemms labourer, James Hartegan labourer, William M'Cauley labourer, Hugh White labourer, Matthew Killroy labourer, William Warren labourer, John Carroll labourer, and Hugh Montgomery labourer, all now reſident in Boſton, in the county of Suffolk, and Hammond Green boat builder, Thomas Greenwood labourer, Edward Manwaring, Eſq and John Munroe, Gentleman, all of Boſton aforeſaid, not having the fear of God before their eyes, but being moved and ſeduced by the inſtigation of the devil and their own wicked hearts, did, on the fifth day of this inſtant March, at Boſton aforeſaid, within the county aforeſaid, with force and arms, feloniouſly, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, aſſault one Criſpus Attucks, then and there being in the peace of God,
and of the ſaid Lord the King, and that he the ſaid William Warren, with a certain hand gun of the value of twenty ſhillings, which he the ſaid William Warren the • and there held in both his hands, charged with gun powder and two leaden bullets, then and there, feloniouſly, wilfully, and of his malice aforethought, did ſhoot off, and diſcharge at and againſt the ſaid Criſpus Attucks, and that the ſaid William Warren, with the leaden bullets as aforeſaid, out of the ſaid hand gun, then and there by force of the ſaid gun powder, ſo ſhot off and diſcharged as aforeſaid, did then and there, feloniouſly, wilfully, and of his malice aforethought ſtrike, penetrate, and wound the ſaid Criſpus Attucks in and upon the right breaſt, a little below the right pap of him the ſaid Criſpus, and in and upon the left breaſt, a little below the left pap of him the ſaid Criſpus, thereby giving to him the ſaid Criſpus, with one of the bullets aforeſaid, ſo ſhot off and diſcharged as aforeſaid, in and upon the right breaſt, a little below the right pap of him the ſaid Criſpus, one mortal wound of the depth of ſix inches, and of the width of one inch; and alſo thereby giving to him the ſaid Criſpus, with the other bullet aforeſaid, ſo ſhot off and diſcharged by the ſaid William Warren as aforeſaid, in and upon the left breaſt, a little below the left pap of him the ſaid Criſpus, one other mortal wound, of the depth of ſix inches, and of the width of one inch, of which ſaid mortal wounds, the ſaid Criſpus Attucks then and there inſtantly died; and that the aforeſaid Thomas Preſton, William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, John Carroll, Hugh Montgomery, Hammond Green, Thomas Greenwood, Edward Manwaring, and John Munroe, then and there, feloniouſly, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, were preſent, aiding, helping, abetting, comforting, aſſiſting, and maintaining the ſaid William Warren, to do and commit the felony and murder aforeſaid.

And ſo the Jurors aforeſaid, upon their ſaid oath, do ſay, that the ſaid Thomas Preſton, William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, Hugh Montgomery, Hammond Green, Thomas Greenwood, Edward Manw • ring, and John Munroe, then and there in manner and form aforeſaid, feloniouſly, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, did kill and
murder the ſaid Criſpus Attucks, againſt the peace of the ſaid Lord the King, his crown and dignity.
div.bibl: JON. SEWALL, Att. pro Dom. Rege. This is a true Bill. WM. TAYLOR, Foreman.
div.p: At the ſame Court the ſaid James Hartegan was indicted for the murder of Samuel Gray; and the ſaid Thomas Preſton, Eſq William Wemms, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carroll, and Hugh Montgomery, for being preſent, aiding, helping and abetting the ſaid James Hartegan to do and commit the felony and murder aforeſaid.

And at the ſame Court the ſaid Matthew Killroy, was indicted for the murder of one Samuel Maverick; and the ſaid Thomas Preſton, William Wemms, William M'Cauley, James Hartegan, Hugh White, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, for being preſent aiding, helping, abetting, and aſſiſting the ſaid Matthew Killroy, to do and commit the felony and murder aforeſaid.

And at the ſame Court the ſaid John Carrol was indicted for the murder of one James Caldwell; and the ſaid Thomas Preſton, William Wemms, William M'Cauley, James Hartegan, Hugh White, William Warren, and Hugh Montgomery, for being preſent aiding, helping, abetting, and aſſiſting the ſaid John Carrol to do and commit the felony and murder aforeſaid.

And at the ſame Court the ſaid Hugh White was indicted for the murder of one Patrick Carr; and the ſaid Thomas Preſton, William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery for being preſent aiding, helping, abetting, and aſſiſting the ſaid Hugh White to do and commit the felony and murder aforeſaid.
On Saturday, the 27th November, 1770, the Court being met, the priſoners were brought into Court and ſet to the bar, when the Court proceeded thus.

div.stage: The Jury were then called over and appeared.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: You the priſoners at the bar, theſe good men, which were laſt called and do now appear, are thoſe who are to paſs between our ſovereign Lord the King and you, upon the trial of your ſeveral lives; if therefore you will challenge them, or any of them, you muſt challenge them as they are called to be ſworn, before they are ſworn, and you ſhall be heard.

The priſoners being aſked whether they would agree in their challenges, conſented that William Wemms ſhould make challenges for them all.

sp.p: N. B. The three laſt being illegally returned, as Jurors, were rejected by the Court, and returned by the Sheriff as taleſmen.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Gentlemen are ye all ſworn.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Priſoners hold up your hands. Gentlemen of the Jury look upon the priſoners, and hearken to the charge. (The Clerk then read the ſeveral indictments againſt them as before ſet forth.) Upon each and every of theſe ſeveral indictments. the priſoners at the bar have been arraigned, and upon their arraignment have pleaded not guilty, and for trial have put themſelves upon God and their country, which country you are; your charge therefore is, to enquire whether they or either of them be guilty of the felony and murder whereof they ſtand indicted, or not guilty. If they or either of them are guilty, you are to ſay ſo; if they or either of them are not guilty, you are to ſay ſo and no more. Good men and true, ſtand together and hearken to your evidence.

div.stage: Samuel Quincy, Eſq addreſſing himſelf to the Court and Jury, opened the cauſe nearly in the following words:

opener.salute: May it pleaſe your Honours, and you Gentlemen of the Jury.

div.p: THE priſoners at the bar, are that party of ſoldiers belonging to his Majeſty's 29th regiment, who in the evening of the 5th of March laſt, were induced from ſome cauſe or other to fire on the inhabitants of this town, in King ſtreet.

They are charged in five diſtinct indictments, with the wilful premeditated murder of five different perſons mentioned in the reſpective bills; to each of theſe indictments, they have ſeverally pleaded, not guilty; and by that plea have thrown upon the crown the burthen of proving the fact alledged againſt them: It is my province therefore to give you evidence in ſupport of this charge, and yours, gentlemen of the Jury, to determine whether they are guilty, or not.

The cauſe is ſolemn and important; no leſs than whether eight of your fellow ſubjects ſhall live or die! A cauſe grounded on the moſt melancholy event that has yet taken place on the continent of America, and perhaps of the greateſt expectation of any that has yet come before a tribunal of civil juſtice, in this part of the Britiſh dominions.

I am aware how difficult, in caſes of this ſort, it ever is, and more eſpecially ſo in theſe times, and in this trial, to preſerve the mind perfectly indifferent; but I remember, we are bound, not only by the natural obligations towards God and man, but alſo by an oath, to examine into the evidence of fact without partiality or prejudice; I need not therefore caution you of your duty in this reſpect: It is upon that evidence and the law reſulting from it, you gentlemen are, in the language of your oath, to give a verdict; and I will venture, before hand, to pronounce that verdict righteous, if it is founded in theſe principles as the rule of your judgment.

It has become my duty, it ſhall therefore be my endeavor, to acquit myſelf in the courſe of this trial with
decency and candour; reflecting, that however intereſting the queſtion may be, the object of our enquiry is ſimply that of truth, and that this enquiry is to be conducted by the wiſdom of the laws and conſtitution.

In ſupport of this accuſation againſt the priſoners at the bar, it is incumbent on the crown, to aſcertain the following things; viz. The indentity of the perſons charged; the fact of killing; and the circumſtances attending and aggravating that fact.

To this end, I ſhall immediately produce to you ſuch evidence, from the teſtimony of credible witneſſes, as may be ſufficient to ſuſtain the ſeveral indictments, and when I have gone through the examination, make ſuch remarks upon it, as may be moſt conciſe and pertinent to the preſent iſſue.
The following witneſſes were then ſworn and examined in their order.
div.stage: Jonathan Williams Auſtin, clerk to John Adams, Eſq ſworn.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Do you know either of the priſoners at the bar?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Which of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: M'Cauley.—I knew the man before, but did not know his name; I was afterwards told it was M'Cauley. On the evening of the 5th of March laſt, I heard the bells ring, and immediately went into King-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many people do you imagine might be there when you got into King-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There might be twenty or thirty I believe.—I ſaw the Sentry at the Cuſtom Houſe door ſwinging his gun and bayonet; there were a parcel of men and boys round him. I deſired them to come away, and not moleſt the Sentry: Some of them came off and went to the middle of the ſtreet; I then left them and went up towards the Main-Guard. Immediately a party came down, I walked by the ſide of them till I came to the Sentry box at the Cuſtom Houſe. M'Cauley then got to the right of the Sentry-box; he was then loading his piece.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near was you to M'Cauley at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was about four feet off: M'Cauley ſaid "Damn you, ſtand off," and puſhed his bayonet at me: I did ſo:—Immediately I heard the report of a gun.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did M'Cauley ſtand to the corner?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He came round the Sentry-box, and ſtood cloſe to it on the right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When the party came down, were there many people there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot really ſay, I think about fifty or ſixty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did they ſay to the people as they came down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not hear them ſay any thing.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear any orders given?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not, either to load or fire.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear the Sen • y cry out for help to the Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; I was not there half a minute.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabouts did you ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſtood inſide the gutter, cloſe by the box.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabout did the Sentry-box ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Three or four feet from the corner of the Cuſtom-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many guns did you hear?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Five or ſix, I cannot ſwear to any particular number.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you look round after you heard the guns fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee M'Cauley then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was he loading again?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think he was; it ſo lies in my mind; (I cannot abſolutely ſwear it.)

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether any ſoldiers ſtood on the right of M'Cauley?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took ſo particular notice of M'Cauley, that I minded no other object.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the priſoners at the bar?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I particularly ſaw that tall man, (pointing to Warren, one of the priſoners.) Next day after the firing in K. ſtreet, I ſaw more of them whom I cannot particularly ſwear to now.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee the ſoldiers before the juſtices on examination?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you then obſerve you had ſeen any of them the night before in King-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was well perſuaded next day in my own mind, that I ſaw that tall one; but a few days after, I ſaw another man belonging to the ſame regiment, ſo very like him, that I doubt whither I am not miſtaken with regard to him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there any other of the party you knew?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am well ſatisfied I ſaw the Corporal there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee White there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the ſituation of the Corporal?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was the corner man at the left of the party.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee either of the perſons, you think you know, diſcharge their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; the man I take to be the tall man, diſcharged his piece as it was upon a level.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee the Corporal diſcharge his gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was behind them in the circle.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What part of the circle did the tall man ſtand in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ſtood next but one to the Corporal. The tall man whoever he was, was the man I ſaw diſcharge his piece.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any thing thrown at the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, there were many things thrown, what they were I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How did the Soldiers ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ſtood with their pieces before them to defend themſelves; and as ſoon as they had placed themſelves, a party, about twelve in number, with ſticks in their hands, who ſtood in the middle of the ſtreet, gave three cheers, and immediately ſurrounded the ſoldiers, and ſtruck upon their guns with their ſticks, and paſſed along the front of the ſoldiers, towards Royal exchange-lane, ſtriking the ſoldiers guns as they paſſed; numbers were continually coming down the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any perſon take hold of any of the guns or bayonets of any of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not remember I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any particular words from this party of twelve.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard no particular words, there was ſuch a noiſe I could not diſtinguiſh any words.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did they load their guns before the people ſurrounded them, or after?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were loading at the time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did they go to the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Very near them, almoſt cloſe to their guns.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the people who ſtruck the guns, there at the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay whether they had gone away or not.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you apprehend the ſoldiers in danger, from any thing you ſaw?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not, indeed.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Where did you ſtand at the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I kept my place. At the time of the firing of the firſt gun, I heard a clattering noiſe on the right like one gun ſtriking againſt another, and immediately the firſt gun was fired from the right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the time of firing that gun was any aſſault made on the perſon that fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ſee the perſon that fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſaid, you ſaw ſeveral blows ſtruck upon the guns, I ſhould like you would make it more plain.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw the people near me on the left, ſtrike the ſoldiers guns, daring them to fire, and called them cowardly • aſ • ls, for bringing arms againſt naked men; bid them lay aſide their guns, and they were their men.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee any perſon fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw Gray fall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He fell in the middle of the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the place where he fell nearly oppoſite to the tall man you talk of?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; the gun that killed him, muſt have been nearer to the center. When the ſoldiers on the left fired, there were fewer people on the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee a molatto among thoſe perſons who ſurrounded the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not obſerve.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they ſeem to be ſailors or town's men.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were dreſſed ſome of them in the habits of ſailors.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any bell ring?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What bell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe all the bells in town were ringing, I heard the Old South firſt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the clattering or blows on the guns to the right, immediately before the firſt gun went off, appear very violent?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, very violent.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was the ſecond gun fired from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be the perſon next to him who fired the firſt, or very near him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Betwixt the firſt and ſecond gun, did you ſee any aſſault given to the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: When the firing came along to the left, were there many people in the ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There were very few people then in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What place did thoſe few ſtand in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Right over the way.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you looking at the perſon who fired the laſt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw him aim at a lad that was running down the middle of the ſtreet, and kept the motion of his gun after him a conſiderable time, and then fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the lad fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He did not, I kept • ay eye on him a conſiderable time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: This ſoldier was towards the left you ſay, was he quite to the left?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not quite, but towards it.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was the lad among the party that ſtruck at the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was paſſing the ſtreet, I cannot ſay where he came from.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After the firing of the firſt gun did the people diſperſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They drew away down Royal-exchange-lane, but others were coming continually down the ſtreet; but when the firſt perſon was killed, they ſeemed all to draw off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people that came down the ſtreet, endeavour to join the party that was ſtriking the ſoldiers, or did they come becauſe of the ringing of the bells?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe they came becauſe the bells were ringing, for they came from all parts of the town, and did not appear to me to join in the aſſault.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe ſeven.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many ſoldiers were of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not count them, but I believe twelve.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know either of the priſoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I know Warren, and ſaw him with the party in King-ſtreet on the evening of the 5th of March laſt—

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the reſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I know them all by ſight, but that is the only perſon I can ſwear to.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The night of the firing, did you ſee the Corporal there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not ſo as to know him; but Warren I can ſwear to.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee him diſcharge his piece?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No: I went away when the firſt gun fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did the perſon ſtand, who fired the firſt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ſtood towards the left of the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabout did you ſtand yourſelf?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Oppoſite the ſoldiers, by Mr. Warden's ſhop the barber.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any body fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw none fall. I went off when the firſt gun was fired, and came back again and heard there were three men killed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you mean the firſt gun was fired from your left, or from the left of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the left of the party; there were two ſtood to the left of Warren.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What appeared to be the conduct of the ſoldiers before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When I got there, they were ſwinging there guns backward and forward, and ſeveral among the people, ſaid, fire, damn you fire; but I think it was Capt. Preſton that gave the word to fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took them to be about fifty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What had they in their hands?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They had nothing in their hands.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any ice or ſnow-balls thrown at the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw ſeveral ſnow balls and pieces of ice thrown, and heard a rattling againſt the barrels of their guns, whether it was ſticks, or what, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did the ſnow-balls ſeem to come from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the people right before the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the ſnow-balls ſeem to be thrown in anger?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know; I ſaw the ſoldiers puſhing at the people before any ſnow balls were thrown.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were the people preſſing on?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were very near, within reach of their bayonets.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any oyſter-ſhells thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the ſnow trodden down, or melted away by the Cuſtom-Houſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, the ſtreet was all covered like a cake.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the priſoners in King-ſtreet on the 5th March.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, before the affray happened.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which of them was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was White. He was ſtanding Sentry at the Cuſtom-houſe: he ſpoke to me, and aſked me how we all did at home. I immediately went home. Soon after I heard the bells ring, and went into King-ſtreet. When I came there, the ſoldiers were drawn up by the Main Guard.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you there at the time of the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you ſpoke to the Sentry, was there any body with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he was walking backwards and forwards by himſelf.

div.p: I am one of the Town watch.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you in King-ſtreet that evening the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. The bells began to ring, and the people cryed fire: I run with the reſt, and went into King-ſtreet; I aſked where the fire was; I was told there was no fire, but that the ſoldiers at Murray's barracks had got out, and had been fighting with the inhabitants, but that they had drove them back again. I went to the barracks, and found the affair was over there. I came back, and juſt as I got to the Town pump, I ſaw twenty or five and twenty boys going into King-ſtreet. I went into King-ſtreet myſelf, and ſaw ſeveral boys and young men about the Sentry box at the Cuſtom houſe. I aſked them what was the matter. They ſaid the Sentry had knocked down a boy. They crowded in over the gutter; I told them to let the Sentry alone. He went up the ſteps of the Cuſtom-houſe, and knocked at the door, but could not get in. I told him not to be afraid, they were only boys, and would not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know the Sentry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is he among the priſoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that's he. (Pointing to White.)

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the reſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that man. (Pointing to Killroy.) The boys were ſwearing and ſpeaking bad words, but they threw nothing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they preſſing on him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were as far as the gutter, and he went up the ſteps and called out, but what he ſaid I do not remember.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did he call loud?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, pretty loud.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: To whom did he call?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know; when he went up the ſteps he levelled his piece with his bayonet fixed. As I was talking with the Sentry, and telling him not to be afraid, the ſoldiers came down, and when they came, I drew back from the Sentry towards Royal-exchange lane, and there I ſtood. I did not ſee them load, but ſomebody ſaid, are you loaded; and Samuel Gray, who was ſhot that night, came and ſtruck me on the ſhoulder, and ſaid, Langford, what's here to pay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſaid you to Gray then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaid I did not know what was to pay, but I believed ſomething would come of it by and bye. He made no reply. Immediately a gun went off. I was within reach of their guns and bayonets; one of them thruſt at me with his bayonet, and run it through my jacket and great coat.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was you then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Within three or four feet of the gutter, on the outſide.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who aſked, are you loaded?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know whether it was the ſoldiers or inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the word given to load?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard the queſtion aſked, whether they were loaded! but I heard no orders to load. Somebody then ſaid, are you all ready: I then heard the word given to fire, twice diſtinctly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there before the ſoldiers at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About forty or fifty, but there were numbers in the lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they nigh the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were not in the inſide of the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had any of the inhabitants ſticks or clubs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know. I had one myſelf, becauſe I was going to the watch, for I belong to the watch.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many ſoldiers were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not count the number of them, about ſeven or eight I think.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was it fired the firſt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where about did he ſtand that fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ſtood on my right, as I ſtood facing them: I ſtood about half way betwixt the box and Royal-exchange-lane. I looked this man (pointing to Killroy) in the face, and bid him not fire; but he immediately fired, and Samuel Gray fell at my feet. Killroy thruſt his bayonet immediately through my coat and jacket;—I ran towards the watch-houſe, and ſtood there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did Killroy ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ſtood on the right of the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he the right hand man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell I believe there were two or three on his right, but I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſpoke to him you ſay before he fired, what did you ſay to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaid either damn you, or God damn you do not fire, and immediately he fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What in particular made you ſay do not fire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hearing the other guns go off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns went off before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Two: but I ſaw nobody fall. Gray fell cloſe to me. I was ſtanding leaning on my ſtick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Gray ſay any thing to Killroy before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ſpoke to nobody but me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he throw any ſnow balls?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nor he had no weapon in his hand; he was as naked as I am now.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any thing thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ſaw nothing at all thrown of any kind.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you talking with Gray at the time the gun went off?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ſpeak with him at that inſtant, but I had been talking with him ſeveral minutes before that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you ſo near Gray, that if he had thrown any thing you muſt have ſeen it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, his hands were in his boſom, and, immediately after Killroy's firing, he fell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any other gun at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: None, till I had got near to the watch-houſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near were the people ſtanding to the ſoldiers, at the time that gun ſhot Gray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were ſtanding near the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any thing hit the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ſaw nothing thrown. I heard the rattling of their guns, and took it to be one gun againſt another. this rattling was at the time Killroy fired, and at my right, I had a fair view of them; I ſaw no body ſtrike a blow nor offer a blow.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you any doubt in your own mind, that it was that gun of Killroy's that killed Gray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No manner of doubt; it muſt have been it, for there was no other gun diſcharged at that time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know the Indian that was killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any body preſs on the ſoldiers with a large cord wood ſtick?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After Gray fell, did he (Killroy) thruſt at him with his bayonet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, it was at me he puſhed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Gray ſay any thing to Killroy, or Killroy to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not to my knowledge, and I ſtood cloſe by him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you perceive Killroy take aim at Gray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not: he was as liable to kill me as him.

div.stage: Francis Archibald, Clerk to Mr. Price, ſworn.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the priſoners in King-ſtreet, that evening of the 5th March.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw Killroy go down with the party towards the Sentry.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took them to be ſix, beſides the Corporal.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the reſt there that you knew?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of them fire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I was not near them; I went to Stone's door.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any ſnow balls or ſticks thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you looking at the party and the people by them before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. There was a noiſe amongſt them; I was not near enough to hear what was ſaid, but I ſaw nothing thrown.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was you when the party came down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Near the middle of the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you obſerve the party to divide themſelves?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; the corporal walked in front of them, as he always does at a relief.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who rung the bell at the Brick meeting houſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any body get in at the windows of the Brick meeting houſe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. In Cornhill ſomebody ſaid ring the bell, but who it was I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which bell rung firſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Old Brick, I believe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee what paſſed betwixt the ſoldiers and others at the barracks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About ten minutes after nine, I ſaw a ſoldier, and a mean looking fellow with him, with a cu • laſs in his hand; they came up to me: ſomebody ſaid, put up your cutlaſs, it is not right to carry it at this time of night. He ſaid, damn you ye Yankie bougers, what's your buſineſs: he came up to another that was with me, and ſtruck him. We beat him back, when ſeven or eight ſoldiers came out of the barracks, with tongs and other weapons; one aimed a blow at a young fellow, John Hicks, who knocked the ſoldier down. As he attempted to riſe, I ſtruck him down again, and broke his wriſt, as I heard afterwards. I went to King-ſtreet, and when the guns were all fired, I ſaw ſeveral perſons dead.

div.p: N. B. The Court being unable to go through this trial in one day, the King's Attorney and the priſoners conſented to the Court's adjourning over night during the Trial, the Jury being kept together in the mean time, by proper officers, appointed and ſworn by the Court for that purpoſe.
div.stage: FIVE o'clock P. M. the Court adjourned to next morning, Wedneſday. NINE o'clock.
Wedneſday, NINE o'clock, the Court met according to adjournment, and proceeded.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Pleaſe look upon the priſoners, do you know any of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I remember this man (pointing to Killroy.)

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you in King ſtreet the fifth of March laſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, in the evening.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Pleaſe to inform the Court and Jury what you ſaw there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I came up Royal-exchange-lane, and as I got to the head of it, I ſaw the Sentry on the ſteps of the Cuſtom-houſe, with his bayonet breaſt high, with a number of boys round him:
—I called to him, and ſaid, I did not think any body was going to do him harm. I ſaw Capt. Preſton and ſome ſoldiers come down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which of the priſoners was the Sentry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I was not ſo high him as to know his face.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many boys were there round him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think about twenty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How old were theſe boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About fourteen or fifteen years old, perhaps ſome of them older, I ſaw no men there except one, who came up Royal-exchange lane with me, thinking it was fire. He went back again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did you take to be the reaſon that the Sentry charged his bayonet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I could not tell what the reaſon was; there was no body troubling him. I was at the corner of Royal-exchange-lane, and a young man went up to the Sentry and ſpoke to him; what he ſaid I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was yo • there in the time of the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I went towards the Sentry-box, there I ſaw Capt. Preſton. I ſaid to him, Sir, I hope you are not going to fire, for every body is going to their own homes. He ſaid I hope they are. I ſaw no more of him. He immediately went in amongſt the ſoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of ſoldiers were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think ſeven or eight, I did not count them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Capt. Preſton lead or follow them down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think he was upon the right of them. As they came down they had their guns charged breaſt high. I ſaw Chriſtopher Monk, who was wounded that night, I turned to ſpeak to him, and directly they fired, and he ſeemed to faulter. I ſaid are you wounded, he ſaid yes. I replied, I do not think it, for I then apprehended they fired only powder.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it the firſt gun that you thought wounded Monk?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of theſe priſoners there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I ſaw Killroy, and that he was the man who ſtruck me with his bayonet, when they came down, before they formed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did any body near you do any violence to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ſaw none.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had you ſeen Monk that evening before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nor the day before.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near were you to the ſoldiers when they fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was about ten or fifteen feet from them, I ſtood in the ſtreet juſt above Royal-exchange-lane, about ſix or ſeven feet from the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you ſee the whole party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they ſtood in a circle, or half moon.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you take notice of the diſtance betwixt the firſt and ſecond gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was your back to them, when the firſt gun was fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, my face was to them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did the firing begin?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Towards the corner of Royal-exchange-lane, I think it was the man quite on the right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the man that ſtruck you do it on purpoſe, or accidentally, do you think?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think he did it on purpoſe, I apprehended it ſo; I was ſtanding by the gutter, and he was before me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Said he any thing to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nor I to him: he came to form, and I was cloſer than I wiſhed I was, and he ſtruck me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How came you to ſpeak to the Sentry, and tell him not to be afraid?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Becauſe he was ſwinging his gun in that manner.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you come up Royal exchange-lane?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I ſaw Doctor Young there, and ſeveral others coming up to know where the fire was; Doctor Young ſaid it was not fire, but that the ſoldiers had made a rumpus, but were gone to their barracks again. Then ſaid I let every man go to his own home.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any thing thrown at the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any body call them names?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any threatning ſpeeches?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; except that the people cryed fire! fire!—the word fire, was in every body's mouth.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Juſt before the firing, when Killrey ſtruck you, was there any thing thrown at the ſoldiers then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw nothing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there a number of people betwixt you and the ſoldiers!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not many.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee Palmes talking with Capt. Preſton?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; I ſaw the molatto fellow there, and ſaw him fall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee a party of people like ſailors, coming down from Jackſon's corner, with ſticks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ſaw none.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you firſt ſee the molatto?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was juſt before me by the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any people coming from Quaker-lane with ſticks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw ſeveral inhabitants coming through that lane, but I ſaw no ſticks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there any coming up Royal-exchange lane?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, numbers, but I ſaw no ſticks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you firſt ſaw the molatto, did you hear him ſay any thing to the ſoldiers, or ſtrike at them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had he a ſtick or club?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not take notice.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any huzzas or cheers as they are called?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard a clamour of the people, but I heard no cheers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear them call the ſoldiers any names?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any body ſay, kill them, damn them knock them over?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the whiſtling about the ſtreets at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any perſon ſtrike with a club at the ſoldiers or any of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee them attempt to ſtrike their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the rattling of the guns as though a ſtick had ſtruck upon them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I heard the people around call fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you take that to be the cry of fire, or bidding the ſoldiers fire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell now what I thought then?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns did you hear fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think ſeven.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the word fire proceed from the people or from the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the people.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there a greater noiſe than uſual, when the bells rang for fire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not think there was ſo much. When I ſaw Dr. Young, he had a ſword in his hand. When I came to King-ſtreet it was as quiet as I ever ſaw it in my life.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the ſword naked or not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſort of a ſword was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did Young ſay to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ſaid it was the beſt way for every body to go home.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did any body huzza for King ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I ſaid, every man home, and the word went round.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did not Dr. Young ſay the ſoldiers were beat to their barracks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; He ſaid they had made a rumpus, and were gone to their barracks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know if Dr. Young went into King-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I left him in the lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the priſoners in King-ſtreet on the evening of the 5th of March laſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Carrel and Montgomery, and White who was the Sentry there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the reſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I do not remember to have ſeen any of the reſt?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you there before the party came down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In what part of the ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was ſtanding along with the Sentry, on the Cuſtom-houſe ſteps; I ſaw a number of boys round the Sentry.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Twenty or thirty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they all boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, none older than ſeventeen or eighteen years old.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did any thing paſs between you and the Sentry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, When I firſt went up to him, I ſaid, what is the matter?—he ſaid he did not know.—The boys were throwing pieces of ice at him, and after I went to him, they threw no more; I ſtood with him five or ſix minutes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee the pieces of ice thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſort of pieces, were they ſmall or were they big enough to hurt a man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, hard and large enough to hurt any man; as big as ones fiſt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he complain any thing about it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ſaid very little to me, only that he was afraid, if the boys did not diſperſe, there would be ſomething very ſoon, he did not mention what.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he tell them to diſperſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he did not ſay a word to them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the pieces of ice hit him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was nothing thrown after I went to him; if any thing was thrown, it was before.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How came you to go to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I went up to him becauſe I knew him, and to ſee what was the matter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear him knock at the door?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he call for any aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not hear him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you there at the time of firing; pleaſe to recollect the circumſtances?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When the ſoldiers came down, Carrol came up to me and clapt his bayonet to my breaſt, and White ſaid do not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was that before the ſoldiers had formed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; immediately on their firſt coming down. I ſtood betwixt the corner of the Cuſtom houſe and the poſt there, with my arm a top of the poſt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the firſt gun fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: From what quarter?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know the man that fired that gun.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was Montgomery, he was the very next perſon to me, cloſe to me. When White told him not to hurt me, he took his hand and puſhed me right behind him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did that firſt ſhot kill or wound any perſon?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſpace of time was it betwixt the firſt and ſecond gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Half a minute, or leſs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any ice or ſnow thrown betwixt the firſt and ſecond gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear any thing ſaid?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was a noiſe among the inhabitants, but I cannot ſay what they ſaid.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any thing thrown before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; Montgomery was knocked down with a ſtick, and his gun flew out of his hand, and when he recovered himſelf he diſcharged his gun.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Do you know where he ſtood at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was the very corner man, on the right, cloſe to me.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Who ſtood next him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know, but the man that ſtood the third from the right was Carrol, and I believe he was the next that fired

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any, body ſtrike Montgomery, or was a club thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The ſtroke came from a ſtick or club that was in ſomebody's hand, and the blow ſtruck his gun and his arm.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was he knocked down, or did the gun only fly out of his hand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He fell I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What with the blow on his arm?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: His gun flew out of his hand, and as he ſtooped to take it up he fell himſelf; the blow ſtruck his arm and might hit his body, for any thing I know.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee the perſon that ſtruck him: was he a tall man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was a ſtout man.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was any number of people ſtanding near the man that ſtruck his gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, a whole crowd, fifty or ſixty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When he took up his gun and fired, which way did he preſent?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Towards Stone's tavern, I imagine he preſented towards the Molatto.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How far diſtant was he from Montgomery when he fell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About fifteen feet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the reſt of the perſons fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. When Montgomery fired, I ſtooped down, and when the ſmoke was gone, I ſaw three lying dead.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the blow Montgomery received, upon the oath you have taken, violent?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, very violent.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you came to the Cuſtom-houſe, and ſaw the boys throwing ice, where did they ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In the middle of King-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they thrown as hard, as they could throw them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I belive they threw them as hard as they could.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there at that time a good deal of ice in K. ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, conſiderable broken ice.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Before the firing, after the party came down, did you ſee any ſnow balls, ſticks, or ice, thrown at the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing ſaid to the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard nothing in particular ſaid to them.—I heard the cry of fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any threats?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, none at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember your examination before the Juſtices?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember your ſaying they were throwing ſticks and cakes of ice, in the mob way.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not at the ſoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any cheers.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I heard two or three cheers.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About two minutes before they fired.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear any thing ſaid to this purpoſe, knock them over! kill them! kill them!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did the people ſeem to be doing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ſtood front of them, and were ſhouting; but I ſaw no violence done, but to that one man.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did the people do immediately on the firing of the firſt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I could not ſee becauſe of the ſmoak.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did Montgomery ſay any thing upon the firing of his gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not a word: nor any of the ſoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee a number of perſons coming up Royal-exchange-lane, with ſticks.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ſaw a number going up Cornhill, and the Molatto fellow headed them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was this before the guard came down or after?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was before the guard came down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many might there be of that party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Betwixt twenty and thirty: they appeared to be ſailors; ſome had ſticks, ſome had none. The Molatto fellow, had a large cord-wood ſtick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they come down King-ſtreet afterwards?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ſee them come down. I did not ſee the molatto afterwards, till I ſaw him dead.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which way was the Molatto with his party going, when you ſaw them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Right towards the Town-pump.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which way did you go into King-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I went up Royal exchange-lane.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How long before the firing, was it, you ſaw them in Cornhill?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Six, ſeven, or eight minutes, I believe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the bells ringing then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did the party with the Molatto do or ſay?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were huzzaing, whiſtling and carrying their ſticks upright over their heads.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of ſticks, do you ſuppoſe might be in the whole?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ſeven or eight I ſuppoſe; ſome of them whiſtling, ſome huzzaing and making a noiſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know their deſign?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: I did not: when they went up Cornhill, I went up Royal-exchange lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any ſoldiers about that time in the ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw a number at Murray's barracks, and ſome officers driving them in.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the priſoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I know Montgomery, I ſaw him in King-ſtreet with the party on the evening of the 5th of March laſt. I was with ſome gentlemen in company, I heard the bells ring after 9 o'clock; I went into King-ſtreet, and I ſaw the Sentry at the Cuſtom-houſe door as uſual, and no body with him: when I came to the Town-houſe, I was told the ſoldiers were abuſing the inhabitants; I aſked where, and was told at Murray's barracks. I went down there, and ſaw four or five ſoldiers, with their guns and bayonets; I told the officer who ſtood by, I was ſurpriſed they ſuffered the ſoldiers to be out at that time of night; an officer ſaid, do you pretend to teach us our duty Sir, I ſaid no, only to remind you of it: You ſee, ſays he, the ſoldiers are in their barracks, why do not you go home. I ſaw Mr. Hickling, he was my neighbour, he ſaid he was going home, we came up as far
• ns the poſt office, where he left me; then I ſaw Mr. Spear,
• he ſaid he was going to his brother David's; when I got to the Town pump, I heard a noiſe, and was told there was a • rumpus at the Cuſtom houſe; I ſaid, I will go down and make peace, he ſaid, you had better not go. I left Mr. Spear, and went down, and ſaw Capt. Preſton at the head of ſeven • or eight ſoldiers, with their guns, and bayonets fixed; I went to Capt. Preſton, and ſaw Mr. Theodore Bliſs talking with him, who ſaid to Capt. Preſton, "Why do you not fire," "God damn you fire." I ſtept betwixt them and aſked Capt. Preſton if the ſoldiers were loaded, he ſaid yes, with powder and ball: I ſaid, I hope Sir you are not going to fire upon the inhabitants, he ſaid by no means: That inſtant I ſaw a piece of ice ſtrike Montgomery's gun, whether • t ſallied him back, or he ſtept one foot back. I do not know, but he recovered himſelf, and fired immediately. I thought he ſtept back and fired, he was the next man to Capt. Preſton, the only ſoldier that was betwixt the Captain and the Cuſtom houſe. When he fired, I heard the word fire, who gave it I do not know. Six or eight ſeconds after that, another ſoldier on the Captain's right fired, and then the reſt one after the other, pretty quick; there was an interval of two or three ſeconds, between the laſt gun but one, and the laſt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know certain, ſeven or eight I believe, I did not count them. Before the laſt gun was fired, Montgomery made a puſh at me with his bayonet, I had a ſtick in my hand, as I generally walk with one, I ſtruck him, and hit his left arm, and knocked his gun down; before he recovered I aimed another ſtroke at the neareſt to me, and hit Capt. Preſton, I then turned and ſaw Montgomery puſhing at me again, and would have puſhed me through, but I threw • ny ſtick in his face, and the third time he ran after me to puſh at me again, but fell down, and I had an opportunity to run down Royal-exchange lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you take notice of the ſituation of the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw the form they were in, they were formed in a half circle.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which way did Montgomery front?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He fronted the watch houſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſtand in a range with the watch houſe and corner of the Cuſtom-houſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you certain that Montgomery was ſtruck and ſall • back before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether it was with a piece of ice or club?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether it hit his body, or his gun, 〈◊〉 both?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It ſtruck both, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any other violence offered, except th • which ſtruck Montgomery and the blows you • emed and gav •

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, no other.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Are you ſure Montgomery did not fall, 〈◊〉 before h • diſcharged his gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Upon the firing the firſt gun, did the people ſeem • retire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they all began to run, and when the reſt we • firing they were a running.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the deceaſed fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No, I did not, but afterwards I ſaw Gray and Attu •
lying.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee all the reſt of the ſoldiers diſcharge the • pieces?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw the ſmoke, and it appeared to me at that tim • they all fired.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: When the laſt gun was fired, where were the people

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were running promiſououſly about every whe •

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Call James Bailey again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you heard Mr. Palmes' teſtimony?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
Are you ſatisfied, notwithſtanding what Mr Pal •
ſays, that Montgomery was knocked down by a blow give him, immediately before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the priſoners at the Rope walks i • the affray there, a few days before the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw Carrol one of the priſoners, there with other ſoldiers in that affray.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the priſoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, the two furtheſt men, Hartegan and Carrol.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee them in King-ſtreet the 5th of March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What time did you come into King-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About a quarter after nine, after the party were come down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were theſe two men of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you there at the time of the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the party diſcharge their muſkets?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, Montgomery.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know him before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any body ſtrike him with a ſtick, or a ſtick thrown at him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabouts did you ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About ten or twelve feet from Capt. Preſton, I ſaw a little ſtick fly over their heads, but I did not perceive it ſtruck any of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How large was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be a piece of a rattan.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any thing at all hit the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you looking at Montgomery when he diſcharged his piece?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any body fall upon his firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw two fall, one fell at my elbow, another about three feet from me. I did not hear the ſound of another gun, before they both fell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they ſtanding before Montgomery.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, about twelve or fifteen feet from him, and about five feet apart, one was the Molatto, the other I did not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you think one gun killed both theſe men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, for I heard no other gun when they fell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you certain the other perſon was killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any other gun before that man fell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the Molatto ſay any thing before the gun went off?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard him ſay nothing. The Molatto was leaning over a long ſtick he had, reſting his breaſt upon it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you in Dock ſquare before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people did you ſee there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw about twenty or thirty gathered up by the Town pump in the market, ſome with clubs; they went up Cornhill, moſt of them dreſt in ſailors cloaths.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you then know where they were going?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ſaid let us go up to the Town-houſe. The bells were ringing at that time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had they in general clubs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The biggeſt part of them had clubs,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of them afterwards in King-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not that I knew

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee a tall man at the head of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I took notice of none in particular.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear a huzzaing before the firing, or ſee any thing thrown except that ſtick you mentioned?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had theſe perſons when they were in Dock ſquare, any clubs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About half of them had ſticks; there were between twenty and thirty of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they hold them up over their heads?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some did, and ſome did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any body with a ſword, at the bottom of Royal exchange lane?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any ſoldiers there, about that time'

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What do you mean by clubs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were cord wood ſticks broken up.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did any of them appear to be large?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were about as thick as one's wriſt.
I came up Royal-exchange-lane, and the firſt I ſaw was Montgomery, I ſaw him puſhing his bayonet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know Montgomery then?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes: I drew back about five feet, and I ſaw his gun go off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did Montgomery ſtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At the corner of the Royal exchange-lane, the right hand man of the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who did he puſh at?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long after that before his gun went off?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About a minute.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had any thing happened betwixt that and the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw a ſtick knock up his gun.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who it was knocked it up?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did you ſtand to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About five feet off, within Royal exchange-lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did that ſtick knock up his gun before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he bring it down before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He brought it down to the place where, it was before, and then he fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you looking at him all the time before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you certain, he did not fall before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you ſure, if he had fallen, you muſt have ſeen him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, from my ſituation I think I muſt have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſort of a ſtick was it his gun was knocked up with?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It looked like a walking ſtick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee him fall after he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What occaſioned his fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any body ſtrike him, or at him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did his gun fall out of his hand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think it did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you ſure that was before, or after his firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: After his firing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near were the people to him at the time of his firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Seven or eight feet off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any other of the priſoners there that night?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſtay till all the guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Six, I think, but I did not count them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the place where you ſtood, could you ſee 〈◊〉 the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, only two, they ſtood in a circular form,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After the firſt gun was fired, did not the people begin to run down the lane?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any words ſpoke by the party of ſoldiers or any of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long did you continue there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About five minutes, not longer: untill all the guns were fired.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you come from Dock-ſquare up to King-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any people there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſaw about twenty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What were they doing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were talking about going home.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were the bells ringing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did they mention any thing why the bells were ringing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ſaid firſt it was fire, and then that the ſoldiers were out.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any cheers given in King-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I did before they fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Two I think.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who gave them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The town's people.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About two minutes before the firing?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How were the people dreſt in Dock ſquare?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some in ſailors cloths, ſome in ſurtouts.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had they ſticks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some had, ſome had not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear them mention their going to the Town-houſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know either of the priſoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I know Montgomery, he uſed to live cloſe by my houſe; I know none of the reſt. I was at home the whole evening, the Old-ſouth bell rung for nine as uſual; about a quarter after, I heard Mr. Cooper's bell ring, I went out and I ſaw the Old ſouth Engine haulled out. I ran down as far as the town-pump, there ſeemed to be a conſiderable body of people, and ſome with buckets. The people out of the chamber windows, ſaid, do not go down there, you will be killed.—I ſaw ten or twelve ſoldiers with naked cutlaſſes by Boylſton's alley:—I ſaw them with their cutlaſſes and bayonets drawing up towards the people. I went back and ſtopped at the Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were there a number of the town's people there at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, and many with buckets in their hands.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were they contending with any body?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No they were ſtanding in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What were the ſoldiers doing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were brandiſhing their ſwords and ſallying up to the people, but I did not tarry there one minute.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What number of people were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thirty or forty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had the perſons the ſoldiers came up to, any thing in their hands?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No they had nothing but buckets. I took it they were brandiſhing their ſwords at the people, but I ſaw them ſtrike no body. I went to the Main Guard, I ſaw the Sentries before the Guard houſe, walking as uſual. I ſtaid on purpoſe to ſee ſome body come back from Boylſton's aſley, to know if any were wounded. People were coming down from the South-end, crying where is the fire? Where is the fire • I ſaid there is no fire, but the ſoldiers fighting. At that time, in King ſtreet, I do not think you could ſee a man, child, or boy paſſing. I ſtood there at the Main Guard about four minutes.—The Old Brick bell began to ring, and the people ſeemed to come along faſt, with buckets and bags.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Mr. Cooper's bell ring before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, a good while.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you ſee the Sentry at the Cuſtom-Houſe where you ſtood?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No, I ſtaid there about five minutes, and in a very ſhort time I looked down King-ſtreet, and ſaw thirty or forty people in King-ſtreet; Capt. Preſton came down to the Main-Guard, as it were from behind the Brick meeting, and ſaid turn out, damn your bloods, turn out: A party of ſoldiers turned out, Montgomery was amongſt them; I was going to Montgomery, to aſk what they were going to do?— They drew up in two files, I think there were eight men, Capt. Preſton drew his ſword, and marched down with them, and I went down as far as Mr. Waldo's ſhop with them, I thought they were going to relieve guard. After that, I went up by the Main guard again, having left the ſoldiers on their march down from Waldo's ſhop, and paſſed round the Town Houſe, came down the north ſide of it, and went down King ſtreet, and got within two yards of the right of them; I ſaw Capt. Preſton ſtanding at the right of
the circle, I ſtaid there about four minutes, when I heard the word given, fire!—There was none fired then.—Then I heard 〈◊〉 your bloods, fire!—Inſtantly one gun went off, I ſaw the fl • ſh of every gun as they went off, one after another, like the clock ſtriking.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did the firing begin?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It began at the right.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee Montgomery after he got down there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Where did you ſtand when the guns were fi • ed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſtood aboue two yards to the right, in Royal-exchange-lane and towards the back of the ſoldiers; I am poſitive the firing began at the right and went on to the left. I counted the guns.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many were fired?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Seven fired, and one fl • ſhed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there a longer diſtance betwixt the firſt and ſecond gun, than betwixt the reſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No more than the reſt, I think.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any man fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not. there was a large opening at the centre, but on the right and left wings the croud was cloſe and thick

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Could you ſee all the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I could not, there were many people between me and the ſoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee the perſon who held the gun that flaſhed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, but I did not know him.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Whereabouts was he ſtanding?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: I believe, by the flaſh, he was the third or fourth man from the fight.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee any thing thrown at any of them before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ſtood all the time they were there, and ſaw nothing thrown at all.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee any body knocked down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: You ſaw no ice nor ſnow balls?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people round you ſeem to be preſſing on ſo as to injure the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; had I ſeen any thing thrown, I would have gone away.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any blows given by any body, before or after the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Palmes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ſaw a man talking with the officer?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Bliſs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any huzzaing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, before the party marched down, there were two or three huzzas, but afterwards none at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people do you imagine were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ſixty or ſeventy.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: From the time they went from the Main-Guard, till the firing, how long was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was not more than ten or twelve minutes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know either of the priſoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, White.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know either of the reſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes Wemms.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Do you know any other?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, Warren and Hartegan, I ſaw them there that night under arms. On Monday evening 5th of March, I was at work near Hancock's wharff, hearing a bell ring it cauſed me to leave the ſhop to make inquiry what the matter was; I heard the ſoldiers had roſe on the inhabitants, and I got as far as Fanuiel-Hall. I ſaw ſeveral gentlemen, I aſked them what the matter was, they anſwered me, that, two young men had been abuſed by the ſoldiers, but that they had returned to their barracks. The bells ſtill ringing made me proceed up Royal-exchange lane with a number of other perſons: I out run them and came to the head of the lane, there being no perſon there but a ſoldier who was the Sentry, the other Inhabitants coming up, they cryed out there is a ſoldier and huzza'd. The ſoldier immediately repaired to the Cuſtom houſe door, he was at the weſt corner of the houſe before; there, with a large braſs knocker, gave three loud and remarkable ſtrokes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of perſons were there came up immediately after you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Five or ſix. Somebody came to the door and opened it, and ſpoke to the Sentry, and then ſhut the door again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was ſaid to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not hear. The ſoldier then turned about and loaded his gun, and knocked it twice very loud on the ſteps; then he went to the weſt corner of the houſe where he had been before, the people gathered round him; I went with him, and I caſt my eye up King-ſtreet, and ſaw an officer and ſeven men, they came to the weſt corner of the Cuſtom-houſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any thing done to moleſt them then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nothing at all. The officer then cryed ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who that officer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have ſeen him in the Court.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many ſoldiers were with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Seven.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How did they ſtand then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ſtood in a circle. The officer then ſaid, handle your arms, eaſe your arms, ſecure your arms, ſupport your arms, eaſe your arms, prime and load.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Are you certain he ſaid all that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am as certain, as I am of my own exiſtence.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did Capt. Preſton ſtand then?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: He ſtood a little behind the ſoldiers towards the Cuſtom-houſe. There were about fifteen or twenty inhabitants in the ſtreet, when the party came down.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were the ſoldiers formed before they loaded?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: They were not really formed: they were in a kind of a circle, after they had loaded they formed more into a circle than they were before.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know Capt. Preſton before that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you there when the guns fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I went up to the officer, and ſaid for God's ſake do not fire on theſe people: he made me no anſwer at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was he then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was ſtanding behind the ſoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you behind the ſoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, a little before them, at the edge of the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any perſon with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, none at all. I puſhed through betwixt two of the men, and ſpoke to him that way, he had on a red cont, and laced hat. I ſaw no more of him. I went to ſome of the inhabitants, and ſaid, do not trouble theſe men, they are on duty. Some ſaid we will neither trouble them, not be drove off by them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any orders given for firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard, damn you fire: it ſeemed to me as it came from the Sentry-box where I left the Captain. I was then by Vernon the barber's ſhop; I had paſſed acroſs the ſtreet. I ſaw a man going to throw a club, I begged of him not to do it, for I ſaid if he did, the ſoldiers would certainly fire: he ſaid, he would not, and did not. I then ſaw a white club thrown at ſome diſtance from me towards the ſoldier's; immediately I heard the word preſent, I ſtooped down, a little ſpace of time enſued, I heard damn you fire: two guns were diſcharged then as I judged.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did that club hit any body?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe it hit one of the ſoldiers guns, I heard it ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was that before the firing, or after?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Before the firing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near to the ſoldiers was the perſon that threw the club?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About ten yards off. Three or four more guns were then diſcharged, which killed Attucks and Cray, I heard and ſaw them fall; then two more were diſcharged, one of them killed Mr Caldwell, who was about ten feet diſtance from me, the other ſtruck about five inches over my back.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſpace of time was there betwixt the ſecond gun and the third?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be about two or three ſeconds. Another gun was then fired, which wounded Mr. Patterſon in the arm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long after the club was thrown, was it, before the firſt gun was fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not above one or two ſeconds.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſort of a ſtick was it that was thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be a white birch cord-wood ſtick, an inch thick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What fort of a man, for heighth, was he that threw it!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He might be about five feet and an half.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How do you know what number of guns were fired together?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I judged by the report: I ſaw the flaſhes,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the perſons that were killed, that evening before they were killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Upon the oath you have taken, did that man throw the ſtick with conſiderable violence, or not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He threw it conſiderable hard, he threw it over hand.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were any people ſtanding betwixt the ſoldiers and the man that threw that ſtick?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, ſome, but not many.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people make a great deal of noiſe and huzzaing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, conſiderable.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear them ſay to the ſoldiers, bloody backs, come on you bloody backs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I heard no ſuch thing, but when the two firſt guns were diſcharged, ſome one cryed murder, and by the voice I think it was Maverick. Theſe guns killed nobody, unleſs Maverick was then ſhot.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ſee any of the priſoners the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not ſo as to know them again. That evening, at the cry of fire, I came out of my houſe, and ſaw the people running down town, and I followed them; when I got by the Town-houſe, I ſaw ſome going down King-ſtreet, I went down alſo: At the Guard houſe, I ſaw a number of the ſoldiers running; I aſked where was the fire, no body anſwered me. I went down to the middle of King-ſtreet, and while I ſtood there, was puſhed from behind me with a bayonet. I turned round and ſaw a party of ſoldiers coming down, I aſked one the reaſon of his puſhing at me? he dumn'd my blood, and bid me ſtand out of their way, I ſaid I would not, I was doing no harm to any man, and would not ſtand aſide for any one; they paſſed me ſome on one ſide, ſome on the other. They came to the Sentry-box, faced round and formed a circle. I ſpoke to ſome of the inhabitants to ſpeak to Preſton, to know what the matter was; ſome body ſpoke to him, but what was ſaid, I do not know. I ſaw Preſton fall in betwixt the fourth and fifth man, the word was given fire! immediately the right hand man fired; after that I puſhed in towards them, and they run a bayonet at me and wounded me in my arm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was it ſtruck you?

sp.speaker: A.
